For ſhe is lumpiſh, heauy, mellancholly,
And (for your friends ſake) will be glad of you;
Where you may temper her, by your perſwaſion,
To hate yong Valentine, and loue my friend.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: As much as I can doe, I will effeƈt:
But you ſir Thurio, are not ſharpe enough:
You muſt lay Lime, to tangle her deſires
By walefull Sonnets, whoſe compoſed Rimes
Should be full fraught with ſeruiceable vowes.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: I, much is the force of heauen-bred Poeſie.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Say that vpon the altar of her beauty
You ſacrifice your teares, your ſighes, your heart:
Write till your inke be dry: and with your teares
Moiſt it againe: and frame ſome feeling line,
That may diſcouer ſuch integrity:
For Orpheus Lute, was ſtrung with Poets ſinewes,
Whoſe golden touch could ſoften ſteele and ſtones;
Make Tygers tame, and huge Leuiathans
Forſake vnſounded deepes, to dance on Sands.
After your dire-lamenting Elegies,
Viſit by night your Ladies chamber-window
With ſome ſweet Conſort; To their Inſtruments
Tune a deploring dumpe: the nights dead ſilence
Will well become ſuch ſweet complaining grieuance:
This, or elſe nothing, will inherit her.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: This diſcipline, ſhowes thou haſt bin in loue.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: And thy aduice, this night, ile put in praƈtiſe:
Therefore, ſweet Protheus, my direƈtion-giuer,
Let vs into the City preſently
To ſort ſome Gentlemen, well skil’d in Muſicke.
I haue a Sonnet, that will ſerue the turne
To giue the on-ſet to thy good aduiſe.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: About it Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: We’ll wait vpon your Grace, till after Supper,
And afterward determine our proceedings.

speech.speaker: Du
speech.line: Euen now about it, I will pardon you.

scene.stagedir: Enter Valentine, Speed, and certaine Out-lawes.

speech.speaker: 1. Out-l.
speech.line: Fellowes, ſtand faſt: I ſee a paſſenger.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: If there be ten, ſhrinke not, but down with ’em.

speech.speaker: 3. Out.
speech.line: Stand ſir, and throw vs that you haue about ’ye.
If not: we’ll make you ſit, and rifle you.

speech.speaker: Sp.
speech.line: Sir we are vndone; theſe are the Villaines
That all the Trauailers doe feare ſo much.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: My friends.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: That’s not ſo, ſir: we are your enemies.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: Peace: we’ll heare him.

speech.speaker: 3. Out.
speech.line: I by my beard will we: for he is a proper man.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Then know that I haue little wealth to looſe;
A man I am, croſs’d with aduerſitie:
My riches, are theſe poore habiliments,
Of which, if you ſhould here disfurniſh me,
You take the ſum and ſubſtance that I haue.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: Whether trauell you?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: To Verona.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: Whence came you?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: From Millaine.

speech.speaker: 3. Out.
speech.line: Haue you long ſoiourn’d there?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Some ſixteene moneths, and longer might haue ſtaid,
If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: What, were you baniſh’d thence?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: I was.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: For what offence?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: For that which now torments me to rehearſe;
I kil’d a man, whoſe death I much repent,
But yet I ſlew him manfully, in fight,
Without falſe vantage, or baſe treachery.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: Why nere repent it, if it were done ſo;
But were you baniſht for ſo ſmall a fault?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: I was, and held me glad of ſuch a doome.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: Haue you the Tongues?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: My youthfull trauaile, therein made me happy,
Or elſe I often had beene often miſerable.

speech.speaker: 3. Out.
speech.line: By the bare ſcalpe of Robin Hoods fat Fryer,
This fellow were a King, for our wilde faƈtion.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: We’ll haue him: Sirs, a word.

speech.speaker: Sp.
speech.line: Maſter, be one of them:
It’s an honourable kinde of theeuery.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Peace villaine.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: Tell vs this: haue you any thing to take to?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Nothing but my fortune.

speech.speaker: 3. Out.
speech.line: Know then, that ſome of vs are Gentlemen,
Such as the fury of vngouern’d youth
Thruſt from the company of awfull men.
My ſelfe was from Verona baniſhed,
For praƈtiſing to ſteale away a Lady,
And heire and Neece, alide vnto the Duke.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: And I from Mantua, for a Gentleman,
Who, in my moode, I ſtab’d vnto the heart.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: And I, for ſuch like petty crimes as theſe.
But to the purpoſe: for we cite our faults,
That they may hold excus’d our lawleſſe liues;
And partly ſeeing you are beautifide
With goodly ſhape; and by your owne report,
A Linguiſt, and a man of ſuch perfeƈtion,
As we doe in our quality much want.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: Indeede becauſe you are a baniſh’d man,
Therefore, aboue the reſt, we parley to you:
Are you content to be our Generall?
To make a vertue of neceſſity,
And liue as we doe in this wilderneſſe?

speech.speaker: 3. Out.
speech.line: What ſaiſt thou? wilt thou be of our conſort?
Say I, and be the captaine of vs all:
We’ll doe thee homage, and be rul’d by thee,
Loue thee, as our Commander, and our King.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: But if thou ſcorne our curteſie, thou dyeſt.

speech.speaker: 2. Out.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt not liue, to brag what we haue offer’d.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: I take your offer, and will liue with you,
Prouided that you do no outrages
On ſilly women, or poore paſſengers.

speech.speaker: 3. Out.
speech.line: No, we deteſt ſuch vile baſe praƈtiſes.
Come, goe with vs, we’ll bring thee to our Crewes,
And ſhow thee all the Treaſure we haue got;
Which, with our ſelues, all reſt at thy diſpoſe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Protheus, Thurio, Iulia, Hoſt, Muſitian, Siluia.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Already haue I bin falſe to Valentine,
And now I muſt be as vniuſt to Thurio,
Vnder the colour of commending him,
I haue acceſſe my owne loue to prefer.
But Siluia is too faire, too true, too holy,
To be corrupted with my worthleſſe guifts;
When I proteſt true loyalty to her,
She twits me with my falſehood to my friend;
When to her beauty I commend my vowes,
She bids me thinke how I haue bin forſworne
In breaking faith with Iulia, whom I lou’d;
And notwithſtanding all her ſodaine quips,
The leaſt whereof would quell a louers hope:
Yet (Spaniel-like) the more ſhe ſpurnes my loue,
The more it growes, and fawneth on her ſtill;
But here comes Thurio; now muſt we to her window,
And giue ſome euening Muſique to her eare.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: How now, ſir Protheus, are you crept before vs?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I gentle Thurio, for you know that loue
Will creepe in ſeruice, where it cannot goe.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: I, but I hope, Sir, that you loue not here.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Sir, but I doe: or elſe I would be hence.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Who, Siluia?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I, Siluia, for your ſake.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: I thanke you for your owne: Now Gentlemen
Let’s tune: and too it luſtily a while.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: Now, my yong gueſt; me thinks your’ allycholly;
I pray you why is it?

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: Marry (mine Hoſt) becauſe I cannot be merry.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: Come, we’ll haue you merry: ile bring you where
you ſhall heare Muſique, and ſee the Gentleman that
you ask’d for.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: But ſhall I heare him ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: I that you ſhall.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: That will be Muſique.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: Harke, harke.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: Is he among theſe?

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: I: but peace, let’s heare’m.
Who is Siluia? what is ſhe?
That all our Swaines commend her?
Holy, faire, and wiſe is ſhe,
The heauen ſuch grace did lend her,
that ſhe might admired be.
Is ſhe kinde as ſhe is faire?
For beauty liues with kindneſſe:
Loue doth to her eyes repaire,
To helpe him of his blindneſſe:
And being help’d, inhabits there.
Then to Siluia, let vs ſing,
That Siluia is excelling;
She excels each mortall thing
Vpon the dull earth dwelling.
To her let vs Garlands bring.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: How now? are you ſadder then you were before;
How doe you, man? the Muſicke likes you not.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: You miſtake: the Muſitian likes me not.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: Why, my pretty youth?

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: He plaies falſe (father.)

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: How, out of tune on the ſtrings.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: Not ſo: but yet
So falſe that he grieues my very heart-strings.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: You haue a quicke eare.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: I, I would I were deafe: it makes me haue a ſlow heart.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: I perceiue you delight not in Muſique.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: Not a whit, when it iars ſo.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: Harke, what fine change is in the Muſique.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: I: that change is the ſpight.

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: You would haue them alwaies play but one thing.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: I would alwaies haue one play but one thing.
But Hoſt, doth this Sir Protheus, that we talke on,
Often reſort vnto this Gentlewoman?

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: I tell you what Launce his man told me,
He lou’d her out of all nicke.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: Where is Launce?

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: Gone to ſeeke his dog, which to morrow, by his
Maſters command, hee muſt carry for a preſent to his
Lady.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: Peace, ſtand aſide, the company parts.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Sir Thurio, feare not you, I will ſo pleade,
That you ſhall ſay, my cunning drift excels.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Where meete we?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: At Saint Gregories well.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Farewell.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Madam: good eu’n to your Ladiſhip.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: I thanke you for your Muſique (Gentlemen)
Who is that that ſpake?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: One (Lady) if you knew his pure hearts truth,
You would quickly learne to know him by his voice.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Sir Protheus, as I take it.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Sir Protheus (gentle Lady) and your Seruant.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: What’s your will?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: That I may compaſſe yours.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: You haue your wiſh: my will is euen this,
That preſently you hie you home to bed:
Thou ſubtile, periur’d, falſe, diſloyall man:
Think’ſt thou I am ſo ſhallow, ſo conceitleſſe,
To be ſeduced by thy flattery,
That has’t deceiu’d ſo many with thy vowes?
Returne, returne, and make thy loue amends:
For me (by this pale queene of night I ſweare)
I am ſo farre from granting thy requeſt,
That I deſpiſe thee, for thy wrongfull ſuite;
And by and by intend to chide my ſelfe,
Euen for this time I ſpend in talking to thee.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I grant (sweet loue) that I did loue a Lady,
But ſhe is dead.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: ’Twere falſe, if I ſhould ſpeake it;
For I am ſure ſhe is not buried.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Say that ſhe be: yet Valentine thy friend
Suruiues; to whom (thy ſelfe art witneſſe)
I am betroth’d; and art thou not aſham’d
To wrong him, with thy importunacy?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I likewiſe heare that Valentine is dead.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: And ſo ſuppoſe am I; for in her graue
Aſſure thy ſelfe, my loue is buried.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Sweet Lady, let me rake it from the earth.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Goe to thy Ladies graue and call hers thence,
Or at the leaſt, in hers, ſepulcher thine.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: He heard not that.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Madam: if your heart be ſo obdurate:
Vouchſafe me yet your Piƈture for my loue,
The Piƈture that is hanging in your chamber:
To that ile ſpeake, to that ile ſigh and weepe:
For ſince the ſubſtance of your perfeƈt ſelfe
Is elſe deuoted, I am but a ſhadow;
And to your ſhadow, will I make true loue.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: If ’twere a ſubſtance you would ſure deceiue it,
And make it but a ſhadow, as I am.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: I am very loath to be your Idoll Sir;
But, ſince your falſehood ſhall become you well
To worſhip ſhadowes, and adore falſe ſhapes,
Send to me in the morning, and ile ſend it:
And ſo, good reſt.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: As wretches haue ore-night
That wait for execution in the morne.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Hoſt, will you goe?

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: By my hallidome, I was faſt asleepe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Pray you, where lies Sir Protheus?

speech.speaker: Ho.
speech.line: Marry, at my houſe:
Truſt me, I thinke ’tis almoſt day.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Not ſo: but it hath bin the longeſt night
That ere I watch’d, and the moſt heauieſt.

speech.speaker: Eg.
speech.line: This is the houre that Madam Siluia
Entreated me to call, and know her minde:
Ther’s ſome great matter ſhe’ld employ me in.
Madam, Madam.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Who cals?

speech.speaker: Eg.
speech.line: Your ſeruant, and your friend;
One that attends your Ladiſhips command.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Sir Eglamore, a thouſand times good morrow.

speech.speaker: Eg.
speech.line: As many (worthy Lady) to your ſelfe:
According to your Ladiſhips impoſe,
I am thus early come, to know what ſeruice
It is your pleaſure to command me in.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Oh Eglamoure, thou art a Gentleman:
Thinke not I flatter (for I ſweare I doe not)
Valiant, wiſe, remorſe-full, well accompliſh’d.
Thou art not ignorant what deere good will
I beare vnto the baniſh’d Valentine:
Nor how my father would enforce me marry
Vaine Thurio (whom my very ſoule abhor’d.)
Thy ſelfe haſt lou’d, and I haue heard thee ſay
No griefe did euer come ſo neere thy heart,
As when thy Lady, and thy true-loue dide,
Vpon whoſe Graue thou vow’dſt pure chaſtitie:
Sir Eglamoure: I would to Valentine
To Mantua, where I heare, he makes aboad;
And for the waies are dangerous to paſſe,
I doe deſire thy worthy company,
Vpon whoſe faith and honor, I repoſe.
Vrge not my fathers anger (Eglamoure)
But thinke vpon my griefe (a Ladies griefe)
And on the iuſtice of my flying hence,
To keepe me from a moſt vnholy match,
Which heauen and fortune ſtill rewards with plagues.
I doe deſire thee, euen from a heart
As full of ſorrowes, as the Sea of ſands,
To beare me company, and goe with me:
If not, to hide what I haue ſaid to thee,
That I may venture to depart alone.

speech.speaker: Egl.
speech.line: Madam, I pitty much your grieuances,
Which, ſince I know they vertuouſly are plac’d,
I giue conſent to goe along with you,
Wreaking as little what betideth me,
As much, I wiſh all good befortune you.
When will you goe?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: This euening comming.

speech.speaker: Eg.
speech.line: Where ſhall I meete you?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: At Frier Patrickes Cell,
Where I intend holy Confeſſion.

speech.speaker: Eg.
speech.line: I will not faile your Ladiſhip:
Good morrow (gentle Lady.)

speech.speaker: Sil
speech.line: Good morrow, kinde Sir Eglamoure.

speech.speaker: Lau.
speech.line: When a mans ſeruant ſhall play the Curre with
him (looke you) it goes hard: one that I brought vp of
a puppy: one that I ſau’d from drowning, when three or
foure of his blinde brothers and ſiſters went to it: I haue
taught him (euen as one would ſay preciſely, thus I
would teach a dog) I was ſent to deliuer him, as a pre-
ſent to Miſtris Siluia, from my Maſter; and I came no
ſooner into the dyning-chamber, but he ſteps me to her
Trencher, and ſteales her Capons-leg: O, ’tis a foule
thing, when a Cur cannot keepe himſelfe in all compa-
nies: I would haue (as one ſhould ſay) one that takes vp-
on him to be a dog indeede, to be, as it were, a dog at all
things. If I had not had more wit then he, to take a fault
vpon me that he did, I thinke verily hee had bin hang’d
for’t: ſure as I liue he had ſuffer’d for’t: you ſhall iudge:
Hee thruſts me himſelfe into the company of three or
foure gentleman-like-dogs, vnder the Dukes table: hee
had not bin there (bleſſe the marke) a piſſing while, but
all the chamber ſmelt him: out with the dog (ſaies one)
what cur is that (ſaies another) whip him out (ſaies the
third) hang him vp (ſaies the Duke.) I hauing bin ac-
quainted with the ſmell before, knew it was Crab; and
goes me to the fellow that whips the dogges: friend
(quoth I) you meane to whip the dog: I marry doe I
(quoth he) you doe him the more wrong (quoth I) ’twas
I did the thing you wot of: he makes me no more adoe,
but whips me out of the chamber: how many Maſters
would doe this for his Seruant? nay, ile be ſworne I haue
ſat in the ſtockes, for puddings he hath ſtolne, otherwiſe
he had bin executed: I haue ſtood on the Pillorie for
Geeſe he hath kil’d, otherwiſe he had ſufferd for’t: thou
think’ſt not of this now: nay, I remember the tricke you
ſeru’d me, when I tooke my leaue of Madam Siluia: did
not I bid thee ſtill marke me, and doe as I do; when did’ſt
thou ſee me heaue vp my leg, and make water againſt a
Gentlewomans farthingale? did’ſt thou euer ſee me doe
ſuch a tricke?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Sebaſtian is thy name: I like thee well,
And will imploy thee in ſome ſeruice preſently.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: In what you pleaſe, ile doe what I can.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I hope thou wilt.
How now you whor-ſon pezant,
Where haue you bin theſe two dayes loytering?

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Marry Sir, I carried Miſtris Siluia the dogge you
bad me.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: And what ſaies ſhe to my little Iewell?

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Marry ſhe ſaies your dog was a cur, and tels you
curriſh thanks is good enough for ſuch a preſent.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: But ſhe receiu’d my dog?

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: No indeede did ſhe not:
Here haue I brought him backe againe.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: What, didſt thou offer her this from me?

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: I Sir, the other Squirrill was ſtolne from me
By the Hangmans boyes in the market place,
And then I offer’d her mine owne, who is a dog
As big as ten of yours, & therefore the guift the greater.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Goe, get thee hence, and finde my dog againe,
Or nere returne againe into my ſight.
Away, I ſay: ſtayeſt thou to vexe me here;
A Slaue, that ſtill an end, turnes me to ſhame:
Sebaſtian, I haue entertained thee,
Partly that I haue neede of ſuch a youth,
That can with ſome diſcretion doe my buſineſſe:
For ’tis no truſting to yond fooliſh Lowt;
But chiefely, for thy face, and thy behauiour,
Which (if my Augury deceiue me not)
Witneſſe good bringing vp, fortune, and truth:
Therefore know thee, for this I entertaine thee.
Go preſently, and take this Ring with thee,
Deliuer it to Madam Siluia;
She lou’d me well, deliuer’d it to me.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: It ſeemes you lou’d not her, not leaue her token:
She is dead belike?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Not ſo: I thinke ſhe liues.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Alas.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Why do’ſt thou cry alas?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I cannot chooſe but pitty her.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Wherefore ſhould’ſt thou pitty her?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Becauſe, me thinkes that ſhe lou’d you as well
As you doe loue your Lady Siluia:
She dreames on him, that has forgot her loue,
You doate on her, that cares not for your loue.
’Tis pitty Loue, ſhould be ſo contrary:
And thinking on it, makes me cry alas.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Well: giue her that Ring, and therewithall
This Letter: that’s her chamber: Tell my Lady,
I claime the promiſe for her heauenly Piƈture:
Your meſſage done, hye home vnto my chamber,
Where thou ſhalt finde me ſad, and ſolitarie.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: How many women would doe ſuch a meſſage?
Alas poore Protheus, thou haſt entertain’d
A Foxe, to be the Shepheard of thy Lambs;
Alas, poore foole, why doe I pitty him
That with his very heart deſpiſeth me?
Becauſe he loues her, he deſpiſeth me,
Becauſe I loue him, I muſt pitty him.
This Ring I gaue him, when he parted from me,
To binde him to remember my good will:
And now am I (vnhappy Meſſenger)
To plead for that, which I would not obtaine;
To carry that, which I would haue refus’d;
To praiſe his faith, which I would haue diſprais’d.
I am my Maſters true confirmed Loue,
But cannot be true ſeruant to my Maſter,
Vnleſſe I proue falſe traitor to my ſelfe.
Yet will I woe for him, but yet ſo coldly,
As (heauen it knowes) I would not haue him ſpeed.
Gentlewoman, good day: I pray you be my meane
To bring me where to ſpeake with Madam Siluia.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: What would you with her, if that I be ſhe?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: If you be ſhe, I doe intreat your patience
To heare me ſpeake the meſſage I am ſent on.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: From whom?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: From my Maſter, Sir Protheus, Madam.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Oh: he ſends you for a Piƈture?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I, Madam.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Vrſula, bring my Piƈture there,
Goe, giue your Maſter this: tell him from me,
One Iulia, that his changing thoughts forget
Would better fit his Chamber, then this Shadow.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Madam, pleaſe you peruſe this Letter;
Pardon me (Madam) I haue vnaduis’d
Deliuer’d you a paper that I ſhould not;
This is the Letter to your Ladiſhip.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: I pray thee let me looke on that againe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: It may not be: good Madam pardon me.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: There, hold:
I will not looke vpon your Maſters lines:
I know they are ſtuft with proteſtations,
And full of new-found oathes, which he will breake
As eaſily, as I doe teare his paper.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Madam, he ſends your Ladiſhip this Ring.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: The more ſhame for him, that he ſends it me;
For I haue heard him ſay a thouſand times,
His Iulia gaue it him, at his departure:
Though his falſe finger haue prophan’d the Ring,
Mine ſhall not doe his Iulia ſo much wrong.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: She thankes you.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: What ſai’ſt thou?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I thanke you Madam, that you tender her:
Poore Gentlewoman, my Maſter wrongs her much.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou know her?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Almoſt as well as I doe know my ſelfe.
To thinke vpon her woes, I doe proteſt
That I haue wept a hundred ſeuerall times.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Belike ſhe thinks that Protheus hath forſook her?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I thinke ſhe doth: and that’s her cauſe of ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Is ſhe not paſſing faire?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: She hath bin fairer (Madam) then ſhe is,
When ſhe did thinke my Maſter lou’d her well;
She, in my iudgement, was as faire as you.
But ſince ſhe did negleƈt her looking-glaſſe,
And threw her Sun-expelling Maſque away,
The ayre hath ſtaru’d the roſes in her cheekes,
And pinch’d the lilly-tinƈture of her face,
That now ſhe is become as blacke as I.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: How tall was ſhe?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: About my ſtature: for at Pentecoſt,
When all our Pageants of delight were plaid,
Our youth got me to play the womans part,
And I was trim’d in Madam Iulias gowne,
Which ſerued me as fit, by all mens iudgements,
As if the garment had bin made for me:
Therefore I know ſhe is about my height,
And at that time I made her weepe a good,
For I did play a lamentable part.
(Madam) ’twas Ariadne, paſſioning
For Theſus periury, and vniuſt flight;
Which I ſo liuely aƈted with my teares:
That my poore Miſtris moued therewithall,
Wept bitterly: and would I might be dead,
If I in thought felt not her very ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: She is beholding to thee (gentle youth)
Alas (poore Lady) deſolate, and left;
I weepe my ſelfe to thinke vpon thy words:
Here youth: there is my purſe; I giue thee this
For thy ſweet Miſtris ſake, becauſe thou lou’ſt her. Farewell.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: And ſhe ſhall thanke you for’t, if ere you know her.
A vertuous gentlewoman, milde, and beautifull.
I hope my Maſters ſuit will be but cold,
Since ſhe reſpeƈts my Miſtris loue ſo much.
Alas, how loue can trifle with it ſelfe:
Here is her Piƈture: let me ſee, I thinke
If I had ſuch a Tyre, this face of mine
Were full as louely, as is this of hers;
And yet the Painter flatter’d her a little,
Vnleſſe I flatter with my ſelfe too much.
Her haire is Aburne, mine is perfeƈt Yellow;
If that be all the difference in his loue,
Ile get me ſuch a coulour’d Perrywig:
Her eyes are grey as glaſſe, and ſo are mine.
I, but her fore-head’s low, and mine’s as high:
What ſhould it be that he reſpeƈts in her,
But I can make reſpeƈtiue in my ſelfe?
If this fond Loue, were not a blinded god.
Come ſhadow, come, and take this ſhadow vp,
For ’tis thy riuall: O thou ſenceleſſe forme,
Thou ſhalt be worſhip’d, kiſs’d, lou’d, and ador’d;
And were there ſence in his Idolatry,
My ſubſtance ſhould be ſtatue in thy ſtead.
Ile vſe thee kindly, for thy Miſtris ſake
That vs’d me ſo: or elſe by Ioue, I vow,
I ſhould haue ſcratch’d out your vnſeeing eyes,
To make my Maſter out of loue with thee.

speech.speaker: Egl.
speech.line: The Sun begins to guild the weſterne skie,
And now it is about the very houre
That Siluia, at Fryer Patricks Cell ſhould meet me,
She will not faile; for Louers breake not houres,
Vnleſſe it be to come before their time,
So much they ſpur their expedition.
See where ſhe comes: Lady a happy euening.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Amen, Amen: goe on (good Eglamoure)
Out at the Poſterne by the Abbey wall;
I feare I am attended by ſome Spies.

speech.speaker: Egl.
speech.line: Feare not: the Forreſt is not three leagues off,
If we recouer that, we are ſure enough.

speech.speaker: Th.
speech.line: Sir Protheus, what ſaies Siluia to my ſuit?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Oh Sir, I finde her milder then ſhe was,
And yet ſhe takes exceptions at your perſon.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: What? that my leg is too long?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: No, that it is too little.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: Ile weare a Boote, to make it ſomewhat rounder.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: But loue will not be ſpurd to what it loathes.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: What ſaies ſhe to my face?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: She ſaies it is a faire one.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: Nay then the wanton lyes: my face is blacke.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: But Pearles are faire; and the old ſaying is,
Blacke men are Pearles, in beauteous Ladies eyes.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: ’Tis true, ſuch Pearles as put out Ladies eyes,
For I had rather winke, then looke on them.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: How likes ſhe my diſcourſe?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Ill, when you talke of war.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: But well, when I diſcourſe of loue and peace.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: But better indeede, when you hold you peace.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: What ſayes ſhe to my valour?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Oh Sir, ſhe makes no doubt of that.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: She needes not, when ſhe knowes it cowardize.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: What ſaies ſhe to my birth?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: That you are well deriu’d.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: True: from a Gentleman, to a foole.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: Conſiders ſhe my Poſſeſſions?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Oh, I: and pitties them.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: Wherefore?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: That ſuch an Aſſe ſhould owe them.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: That they are out by Leaſe.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Here comes the Duke.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: How now ſir Protheus; how now Thurio?
Which of you ſaw Eglamoure of late?

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: Not I.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Saw you my daughter?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Neither.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Why then
She’s fled vnto that pezant, Valentine;
And Eglamoure is in her Company:
’Tis true: for Frier Laurence met them both
As he, in pennance wander’d through the Forreſt:
Him he knew well: and gueſd that it was ſhe,
But being mask’d, he was not ſure of it.
Beſides ſhe did intend Confeſſion
At Patricks Cell this euen, and there ſhe was not.
Theſe likelihoods confirme her flight from hence;
Therefore I pray you ſtand, not to diſcourſe,
But mount you preſently, and meete with me
Vpon the riſing of the Mountaine foote
That leads toward Mantua, whether they are fled:
Diſpatch (ſweet Gentlemen) and follow me.

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: Why this it is, to be a peeuiſh Girle,
That flies her fortune when it followes her:
Ile after; more to be reueng’d on Eglamoure,
Then for the loue of reck-leſſe Siluia.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: And I will follow, more for Siluias loue
Then hate of Eglamoure that goes with her.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: And I will follow, more to croſſe that loue
Then hate for Siluia, that is gone for loue.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: Come, come be patient:
We muſt bring you to our Captaine.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: A thouſand more miſchances then this one
Haue learn’d me how to brooke this patiently.

speech.speaker: 2 Out.
speech.line: Come, bring her away.

speech.speaker: 1 Out.
speech.line: Where is the Gentleman that was with her?

speech.speaker: 3 Out.
speech.line: Being nimble footed, he hath out-run vs.
But Moyſes and Valerius follow him:
Goe thou with her to the Weſt end of the wood,
There is our Captaine: Wee’ll follow him that’s fled,
The Thicket is beſet, he cannot ſcape.

speech.speaker: 1. Out.
speech.line: Come, I muſt bring you to our Captains caue.
Feare not: he beares an honourable minde,
And will not vſe a woman lawleſly.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: O Valentine: this I endure for thee.

scene.stagedir: Enter Valentine, Protheus, Siluia, Iulia, Duke, Thurio, Out-lawes.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: How vſe doth breed a habit in a man?
This ſhadowy deſart, vnfrequented woods
I better brooke then flouriſhing peopled Townes:
Here can I ſit alone, vn-ſeene of any,
And to the Nightingales complaining Notes
Tune my diſtreſtes, and record my woes.
O thou that doſt inhabit in my breſt,
Leaue not the Manſion ſo long Tenant-leſſe,
Leſt growing ruinous, the building fall,
And leaue no memory of what it was,
Repaire me, with thy preſence, Siluia:
Thou gentle Nimph, cheriſh thy for-lorne ſwaine.
What hallowing, and what ſtir is this to day?
Theſe are my mates, that make their wills their Law,
Haue ſome vnhappy paſſenger in chace;
They loue me well: yet I haue much to doe
To keepe them from vnciuill outrages.
Withdraw thee Valentine: who’s this comes heere?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Madam, this ſeruice I haue done for you
(Though you reſpeƈt not aught your ſeruant doth)
To hazard life, and reskew you from him,
That would haue forc’d your honour, and your loue,
Vouchſafe me for my meed, but one faire looke:
(A ſmaller boone then this I cannot beg,
And leſſe then this, I am ſure you cannot giue.)

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: How like a dreame is this? I ſee, and heare:
Loue, lend me patience to forbeare a while.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: O miſerable, vnhappy that I am.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Vnhappy were you (Madam) ere I came:
But by my comming, I haue made you happy.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: By thy approach thou mak’ſt me moſt vnhappy.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: And me, when he approcheth to your preſence.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Had I beene ceazed by a hungry Lion,
I would haue beene a break-faſt to the Beaſt,
Rather then haue falſe Protheus reskue me:
Oh heauen be iudge how I loue Valentine,
Whoſe life’s as tender to me as my ſoule,
And full as much (for more there cannot be)
I doe deteſt falſe periur’d Protheus:
Therefore be gone, ſollicit me no more.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: What dangerous aƈtion, ſtood it next to death
Would I not vndergoe, for one calme looke:
Oh ’tis the curſe in Loue, and ſtill approu’d
When women cannot loue, where they’re belou’d.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: When Protheus cannot loue, where he’s belou’d:
Read ouer Iulia’s heart, (thy firſt beſt Loue)
For whoſe deare ſake, thou didſt then rend thy faith
Into a thouſand oathes; and all thoſe oathes,
Deſcended into periury, to loue me,
Thou haſt no faith left now, vnleſſe thou’dſt two,
And that’s farre worſe then none: better haue none
Then plurall faith, which is too much by one:
Thou Counterfeyt, to thy true friend.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: In Loue,
Who reſpeƈts friend?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: All men but Protheus.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Nay, if the gentle ſpirit of mouing words
Can no way change you to a milder forme;
Ile wooe you like a Souldier, at armes end,
And loue you ’gainſt the nature of Loue: force ye.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Oh heauen.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Ile force thee yeeld to my deſire.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Ruffian: let goe that rude vnciuill touch,
Thou friend of an ill faſhion.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Valentine.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Thou cōmon friend, that’s without faith or loue,
For ſuch is a friend now: treacherous man,
Thou haſt beguil’d my hopes; nought but mine eye
Could haue perſwaded me: now I dare not ſay
I haue one friend aliue; thou wouldſt diſproue me:
Who ſhould be truſted, when ones right hand
Is periured to the boſome? Protheus
I am ſorry I muſt neuer truſt thee more,
But count the world a ſtranger for thy ſake:
The priuate wound is deepeſt: oh time, moſt accurſt.
’Mongſt all foes that a friend ſhould be the worſt?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: My ſhame and guilt confounds me:
Forgiue me Valentine: if hearty ſorrow
Be a ſufficient Ranſome for offence,
I tender’t heere: I doe as truely ſuffer,
As ere I did commit.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Then I am paid:
And once againe, I doe receiue thee honeſt;
Who by Repentance is not ſatisfied,
Is nor of heauen, nor earth; for theſe are pleas’d:
By Penitence th’ Eternalls wrath’s appeas’d:
And that my loue may appeare plaine and free,
All that was mine, in Siluia, I giue thee.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Oh me vnhappy.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Looke to the Boy.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Why, Boy?
Why wag: how now? what’s the matter? look vp: ſpeak.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: O good ſir, my maſter charg’d me to deliuer a ring
to Madam Siluia: ẃ (out of my negleƈt) was neuer done.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Where is that ring? boy?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Heere ’tis: this is it.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: How? let me ſee.
Why this is the ring I gaue to Iulia.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Oh, cry you mercy ſir, I haue miſtooke:
This is the ring you ſent to Siluia.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: But how cam’ſt thou by this ring? at my depart
I gaue this vnto Iulia.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: And Iulia her ſelfe did giue it me,
And Iulia her ſelfe hath brought it hither.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: How? Iulia?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Behold her, that gaue ayme to all thy oathes,
And entertain’d ’em deepely in her heart.
How oft haſt thou with periury cleft the roote?
Oh Protheus, let this habit make thee bluſh.
Be thou aſham’d that I haue tooke vpon me,
Such an immodeſt rayment; if ſhame liue
In a diſguiſe of loue?
It is the leſſer blot modeſty findes,
Women to change their ſhapes, then men their minds.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Then men their minds? tis true: oh heuen, were man
But Conſtant, he were perfeƈt; that one error
Fils him with faults: makes him run through all th’ſins;
Inconſtancy falls-off, ere it begins:
What is in Siluia’s face, but I may ſpie
More freſh in Iulia’s with a conſtant eye?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Come, come: a hand from either:
Let me be bleſt to make this happy cloſe:
’Twere pitty two ſuch friends ſhould be long foes.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Beare witnes (heauen) I haue my wiſh for euer.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: And I mine.

speech.speaker: Out-l.
speech.line: A prize: a prize: a prize.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Forbeare, forbeare I ſay: It is my Lord the Duke.
Your Grace is welcome to a man diſgrac’d,
Baniſhed Valentine.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Sir Valentine?

speech.speaker: Thu.
speech.line: Yonder is Siluia: and Siluia’s mine.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Thurio giue backe; or elſe embrace thy death:
Come not within the meaſure of my wrath:
Doe not name Siluia thine: if once againe,
Verona ſhall not hold thee: heere ſhe ſtands,
Take but poſſeſſion of her, with a Touch:
I dare thee, but to breath vpon my Loue.

speech.speaker: Thur.
speech.line: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I:
I hold him but a foole that will endanger
His Body, for a Girle that loues him not:
I claime her not, and therefore ſhe is thine.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: The more degenerate and baſe art thou
To make ſuch meanes for her, as thou haſt done,
And leaue her on ſuch ſlight conditions.
Now, by the honor of my Anceſtry,
I doe applaud thy ſpirit, Valentine,
And thinke thee worthy of an Empreſſe loue:
Know then, I heere forget all former greefes,
Cancell all grudge, repeale thee home againe,
Plead a new ſtate in thy vn-riual’d merit,
To which I thus ſubſcribe: Sir Valentine,
Thou art a Gentleman, and well deriu’d,
Take thou thy Siluia, for thou haſt deſeru’d her.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: I thank your Grace, ý gift hath made me happy:
I now beſeech you (for your daughters ſake)
To grant one Boone that I ſhall aske of you.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I grant it (for thine owne) what ere it be.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Theſe baniſh’d men, that I haue kept withall,
Are men endu’d with worthy qualities:
Forgiue them what they haue committed here,
And let them be recall’d from their Exile:
They are reformed, ciuill, full of good,
And fit for great employment (worthy Lord.)

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Thou haſt preuaild, I pardon them and thee:
Diſpoſe of them, as thou knowſt their deſerts.
Come, let vs goe, we will include all iarres,
With Triumphes, Mirth, and rare ſolemnity.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: And as we walke along, I dare be bold
With our diſcourſe, to make your Grace to ſmile.
What thinke you of this Page (my Lord?)

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I think the Boy hath grace in him, he bluſhes.

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: I warrant you (my Lord) more grace, then Boy.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What meane you by that ſaying?

speech.speaker: Val.
speech.line: Pleaſe you, Ile tell you, as we paſſe along,
That you will wonder what hath fortuned:
Come Protheus, ’tis your pennance, but to heare
The ſtory of your Loues diſcouered.
That done, our day of marriage ſhall be yours,
One Feaſt, one houſe, one mutuall happineſſe.

personae.persnames: The names of all the Aƈtors.
personae.persona: Thurio: a fooliſh riuall to Valentine.
Eglamoure: Agent for Siluia in her eſcape.
Speed: a clowniſh ſeruant to Valentine.
